body:
If you haven’t already, check out our [contributing guidelines](https://github.com/Expensify/ReactNativeChat/blob/main/contributingGuides/CONTRIBUTING.md) for onboarding and email contributors@expensify.com to request to join our Slack channel! ___ **Version Number:** 9.2.41-0 **Reproducible in staging?:** Y **Reproducible in production?:** Y **If this was caught during regression testing, add the test name, ID and link from TestRail:** https://test-management.browserstack.com/projects/2219752/test-runs/TR-1594/folder/13176707/41236876/983218013 **Email or phone of affected tester (no customers):** kiatest.80+ck103025@gmail.com **Issue reported by:** Applause - Internal Team ## Action Performed: Preconditions: 1. Admin - User is an Admin of a Control workspace where report fields with the types of text, date, formula and list (I added 2 types of text field, one each of date & list & formula type) have been created & initial values set up 2. Admin - has enabled tags & taxes features 3. Admin - has invited employee to workspace 4. Admin - Log out of account 1. Employee - Navigate to staging.new.expensify.com 2. Employee - Go to workspace chat & create expense 3. Admin - Navigate to staging.new.expensify.com & log in 4. Go to employee's workspace expense 5. Open the expense details 6. Try scrolling the expense details & observe page cannot be scrolled 7. Go back to expense preview & reopen the details page 8. Observe scrollbar appears & page can be scrolled completely ## Expected Result: On step 6 - Admin should be able to easily scroll the expense details page completely to view the details ## Actual Result: On step 6 - Admin cannot scroll & view the employee's expense details as scrollbar is missing. When admin navigates back to expense preview & revisit the details page, scrollbar is displayed and able to view the expense details Note: 1. Issue happens every time when admin logs out & log back in 2. Issue occurs on employee side too when he sign out & sign in back ## Workaround: Unknown ## Platforms: Select the officially supported platforms where the issue was reproduced: - [ ] Android: App - [ ] Android: mWeb Chrome - [x] iOS: App - [x] iOS: mWeb Safari - [ ] iOS: mWeb Chrome - [x] Windows: Chrome - [ ] MacOS: Chrome / Safari - [ ] MacOS: Desktop

title: $125 DRY up code that cleans up reports when policies are deleted

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Daily
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Help Wanted
labels.description: Apply this label when an issue is open to proposals by contributors

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

body:
# Problem
We have some code that cleans up reports when a policy is deleted. That code has been duplicated in 3-4 files and is redundant.

### Solution
- Search the code for `// If we are deleting a policy, we have to check every report linked to that policy`
- You will find 3-4 instances of this
- Remove all but one of them
- Verify the functionality still works as intended

<details><summary>Issue Owner</summary>Current Issue Owner: @linhvovan29546</details>

As User B, open the chat room and add an attachment, but do not send the attachment at the final step. 5. As User A, change the Who can post setting for the chat room to Only admins. 6. title: [$250] Restore Type Safety for Onyx.update()

labels.name: External
labels.description: Added to denote the issue can be worked on by a contributor

labels.name: Daily
labels.description: KSv2

labels.name: Bug
labels.description: Something is broken. Auto assigns a BugZero manager.

body:
## Background: The frontend frequently reads and writes data to the backend using the Onyx data layer. Whenever a request is made, we optimistically set Onyx data via Onyx.update(). First updating the local cache, then syncing changes once the request succeeds/fails. During the migration to TypeScript, @fabioh8010 and I ensured this function and accompanying types were type-safe, meaning only values defined in the Onyx schema could be set under a specific key. This safeguard protected against corrupted data, unexpected keys, and typos in key names, improving developer experience and data reliability. ## Problem: It's possible to set any value to any key when using Onyx.update(): ```ts const optimisticData: OnyxUpdate[] = [ { onyxMethod: Onyx.METHOD.MERGE, key: ONYXKEYS.IS_LOADING_REPORT_DATA, // boolean value: 'whatever value', // this doesn't raise a type error }, ]; ``` ## Solution: Reintroduce the previous type definition in react-native-onyx (as it was implemented before PR #600) to restore schema-based type enforcement. Then: Update react-native-onyx in E/App. Resolve around 120 resulting type errors in E/App This change will restore strict type safety for Onyx.update(), preventing invalid data assignments at compile-time. In React-native-onyx this will also be included: - add a comment above this magic type so that nobody touches it again - add type tests to Onyx
